column4: UPDATE 2-Canada's Rogers Communications revenue boosted by cable power
column5: (Adds details)
column6: April 21 (Reuters) - Canadian telecoms operator Rogers Communications Inc trumped first-quarter revenue estimates on Wednesday, buoyed by strong demand in its cable unit that provides internet and cloud-based services.
column7: Total revenue rose 2% to C$3.49 billion ($2.77 billion) in the quarter, compared with analysts’ average estimate of C$3.35 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column8: Telecom providers have benefited from a surge in demand for high-speed internet from the COVID-19 pandemic caused shift to remote working and entertainment.
column9: Revenue from the media segment, which includes television, radio broadcasting and digital media, rose 7% to C$440 million, boosted by the return of live professional sports broadcasting.
column10: Cable service revenue increased 5% during the quarter.
column11: Rogers, which is looking to expand its 5G infrastructure, said in March it was buying Canadian telecom services provider Shaw Communications Inc for about C$20 billion ($16.02 billion).
column12: However, the company’s wireless service reported a 6% drop in revenue, hit by lower roaming revenue from fresh pandemic-induced travel curbs.
column13: Net income rose to C$361 million, or 70 Canadian cents per share, from C$352 million, or 68 Canadian cents, a year earlier.
column14: Excluding items, the company earned 77 Canadian cents per share, while analysts had expected 66 Canadian cents.
column15: U.S.-listed shares of Rogers, which did not provide second-quarter forecast due to pandemic-led uncertainty, rose nearly 1% in low pre-market trading volumes.

column4: CORRECTED-UPDATE 1-Solid demand for cable unit boosts Rogers Communications' revenue
column5: (Corrects to say net income rose, not fell, in paragraph 6)
column6: April 21 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc on Wednesday reported first-quarter revenue that trumped analysts’ estimates, as demand for its cable unit, which include internet and cloud-based services, helped boost the Canadian telecom operator’s sales.
column7: The company’s total revenue rose to C$3.49 billion ($2.77 billion) in the quarter, compared with analysts’ average estimates of C$3.35 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column8: Rogers, which owns the Toronto Blue Jays baseball team, saw a recovery in its ad sales as live sports returned to television after months following the pandemic-induced lockdowns.
column9: The company reported a 5% increase in its cable service revenue.
column10: Revenue from the media segment, which includes television, radio broadcasting and digital media, rose 7% to C$440 million, due to a recovery in company’s ad business.
column11: Net income rose to C$361 million, or 70 Canadian cents per share, from C$352 million, or 68 Canadian cents, a year earlier.
column12: The results come as Rogers is looking to shake up the Canadian telecoms industry with a C$20 billion bid for Shaw Communications Inc.

column4: Canada's Rogers Communications beats quarterly revenue estimates
column5: April 21 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc on Wednesday reported first-quarter revenue that trumped analysts’ estimates, as more live sports on television helped boost the Canadian telecom operator’s advertisement sales.
column6: The company’s total revenue rose to C$3.49 billion ($2.77 billion) in the quarter, compared with analysts’ average estimates of C$3.35 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: The results come as Rogers is looking to shake up the Canadian telecoms industry with a C$20 billion bid for Shaw Communications Inc.

column4: Rogers wireless service back for majority of users following outage
column5: Rogers Communications Inc (RCIb.TO) said late on Monday its services had been restored for most of its users, following intermittent interruptions to wireless voice and data services for several hours.
column6: "Wireless calls, SMS and data services are now restored for the vast majority of our customers", the company said on Twitter. (https://bit.ly/32rx8HL)
column7: The company said earlier on Monday that its residential and business wireline internet services were not impacted. (https://bit.ly/3sAqs4B)
column8: About 11,000 users in Canada reported issues with the wireless service provider, as of 1900 GMT on Monday, according to outage monitoring website Downdetector.ca.
column9: Downdetector tracks outages by collating status reports from a series of sources, including user-submitted errors on its platform. The outage could have affected a larger number of users.

column4: Thousands of Rogers wireless service users report outage
column5: Rogers Communications Inc (RCIb.TO) said late on Monday its services had been restored for most of its users, following intermittent interruptions to wireless voice and data services for several hours.
column6: "Wireless calls, SMS and data services are now restored for the vast majority of our customers", the company said on Twitter. (https://bit.ly/32rx8HL)
column7: The company said earlier on Monday that its residential and business wireline internet services were not impacted. (https://bit.ly/3sAqs4B)
column8: About 11,000 users in Canada reported issues with the wireless service provider, as of 1900 GMT on Monday, according to outage monitoring website Downdetector.ca.
column9: Downdetector tracks outages by collating status reports from a series of sources, including user-submitted errors on its platform. The outage could have affected a larger number of users.

column4: Rogers, Shaw merger will result in competition, Shaw CEO tells committee
column5: VANCOUVER (Reuters) - The merger of Rogers Communications Inc and Shaw Communications Inc would result in sufficient market competition, Shaw’s chief executive said on Monday, as a Canadian parliamentary committee grilled the telecom firms’ officials on anti-trust aspects of the deal.
column6: Rogers agreed to buy Shaw in a C$20 billion ($16 billion) deal that would create Canada’s second-largest cellular and cable operator. But the Canadian government was quick to say it would attract stiff regulatory scrutiny.
column7: “I truly believe that these two companies coming together and the investments that are going to be made, there will be as much competition in the future as there was in the past,” Shaw CEO Brad Shaw told a parliamentary committee in a livestreamed hearing.
column8: The deal represents Rogers’ second attempt in less than six months to consolidate Canada’s concentrated telecoms market, where the top three operators control about 90% of the C$53.1 billion market. Rogers’ effort to buy Cogeco Inc’s Canadian assets was rebuffed by Cogeco’s top shareholder in September.
column9: Last year, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s minority Liberal government ordered Canada’s top three telecom operators to cut prices on their mid-range wireless service plans by 25% within two years or face regulatory action.

column4: UPDATE 1-Rogers, Shaw merger will result in competition, CEOs tell committee
column5: (Adds details from hearing)
column6: VANCOUVER, March 29 (Reuters) - A merger of Rogers Communications Inc and Shaw Communications Inc would result in sufficient market competition, their chief executives said on Monday, as a Canadian parliamentary committee grilled the firms’ officials on anti-trust aspects of the deal.
column7: Rogers agreed to buy Shaw in a C$20 billion ($16 billion) deal that would create Canada’s second-largest cellular and cable operator. But the Canadian government was quick to say it would attract stiff regulatory scrutiny.
column8: “I truly believe that these two companies coming together and the investments that are going to be made, there will be as much competition in the future as there was in the past,” Shaw CEO Brad Shaw told a parliamentary committee in a livestreamed hearing.
column9: The deal represents Rogers’ second attempt in less than six months to consolidate Canada’s concentrated C$53.1 billion telecoms market, in which the top three operators control about 90%. Rogers’ effort to buy Cogeco Inc’s Canadian assets was rebuffed by Cogeco’s top shareholder in September.
column10: Competition will not be “lessened because of this change; if anything it will be intensified,” Rogers CEO Joe Natale told the committee.
column11: Both men repeatedly deferred to the government’s regulatory review process when pressed on measures such as divesting Shaw’s Freedom Mobile, a smaller telecoms carrier.
column12: The deal has triggered particular concern about Canada’s upcoming 5G spectrum auction, which was delayed for a year due to the COVID-19 pandemic and is scheduled for June.
column13: Smaller companies will be hard-pressed to participate, said Anthony Lacavera, a Canadian telecoms executive who originally founded what is now Freedom Mobile, because of the challenges of raising capital in a consolidated market.
column14: “I’d be going to investors and saying, ‘We’re not sure that we can get any of the spectrum, and the rules don’t really allow us to ensure we get any,’” Lacavera said.
column15: Canada’s mobile wireless plans are among the most expensive in the world, according to the most recent government study from 2019.
column16: Last year, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s minority Liberal government ordered Canada’s top three telecom operators to cut prices on their mid-range wireless service plans by 25% within two years or face regulatory action.
column17: Rogers’ shares were up 1% after the hearing, while Shaw’s were up by 0.35%. (Reporting by Moira Warburton in Vancouver; Editing by Dan Grebler)

column4: Rogers' 'sweeteners' for $16 billion Shaw takeover may test Canadian regulatory, political patience
column5: TORONTO (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc’s efforts to secure its C$20 billion ($16 billion) acquisition of Shaw Communications Inc could be insufficient to overcome regulatory hurdles and political opposition amid concerns Canadians face some of the world’s highest phone bills.
column6: Rogers agreed on Monday to buy Shaw in a deal that would create Canada’s second-largest cellular and cable operator, but the Canadian government was quick to say it would attract stiff regulatory scrutiny.
column7: Analysts and fund managers say the company is facing an uphill battle closing the deal even as it has offered some incentives such as committing to maintaining affordable wireless plans with Shaw’s Freedom Mobile carrier for three years, investing C$2.5 billion over the next five years to build out 5G in Western Canada, among others.
column8: While Shaw shares surged on the bid, they closed 16.4% below Rogers’ offer price, which investors said reflected the regulatory uncertainty.
column9: The deal represents Rogers’ second attempt in less than six months to consolidate Canada’s concentrated telecoms market, where the top three operators control about 90% of the C$53.1 billion market. Rogers’ effort to buy Cogeco Inc’s Canadian assets was rebuffed by Cogeco’s top shareholder in September.
column10: The deal suggests that both Shaw and Rogers had already “beaten the doors down in Ottawa ahead of time and tried to suss things out,” said Lawrence Surtees, lead communications analyst for IDC Canada.
column11: But “the jury is still out” on whether regulators will approve it despite “all the little sweeteners in the deal,” he said, also pointing to Rogers’ promise to create a C$1 billion broadband fund.
column12: Higher concentration in wireless business is emerging as an area of concern as the deal would cut the number of wireless providers to three from four in Ontario, Alberta and British Columbia, which constitute 67% of Canada’s population, BMO Capital Markets analyst Tim Casey wrote in a note.
column13: It is “no sure thing” that the deal will win the blessing of regulators, he added.
column14: A top-ten shareholder in Shaw said the deal comes with regulatory risk, particularly in Ontario.
column15: “That’s really where you would see them push up against the 50% benchmark,” the shareholder said, referring to the size of the market share Rogers and Shaw would have in Ontario after the deal, adding that a solution could be divesting some assets.
column16: Rogers did not respond to a request for comment on the question of asset sales.
column17: When Canadian telecom company Bell Canada took over Manitoba Telecom Services in 2017, it agreed to sell one-third of the company’s monthly contract wireless customers and one-third of brick-and-mortar stores to Telus Corp.
column18: The shareholder said Rogers would likely be willing to offload some assets in the east of the country, since the deal’s value is in wireline infrastructure in western Canada. So-called ‘wireline’ assets transmit information using a physical wire and are considered key to the rollout of 5G.
column19: “If we have to sell C$2 billion of assets in the east, that’s fine,” said the top shareholder.
column20: Canadian Innovation Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne said the review would focus on “affordability, competition, and innovation.”
column21: The deal could attract extra attention in a year when Canada looks likely to have a federal election. Canada’s telecoms industry came under fire ahead of the last federal election, with voters complaining about cellphone bills, which are among the highest in the world.
column22: In March, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s minority Liberal government ordered Canada’s top three telecom operators to cut prices on their mid-range wireless service plans by 25% within two years or face regulatory action.
column23: Jason Kenney, premier of Alberta, where Shaw is based, said on Monday his government would monitor regulatory filings closely and likely make its own submissions to federal agencies.
column24: “In particular we’ll seek to have the commitments that it (Rogers) has made - increased employment and investment - made a condition of federal regulatory approval,” Kenney said.

column4: Rogers' $16 billion bid for Shaw shakes up Canadian telecoms industry, may irk regulators
column5: (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc said on Monday it was buying Shaw Communications Inc for about C$20 billion ($16.02 billion) in a deal that would create Canada’s second-largest cellular and cable operator but might attract stiff regulatory scrutiny.
column6: By acquiring fourth-ranked Shaw, Rogers would leapfrog Telus Corp and take on market leader BCE Inc in the highly competitive Canadian telecommunications industry.
column7: Rogers, whose business is concentrated in the urban centers of Ontario, is also expected to gain from Shaw’s strong presence in the sparsely populated regions of Western Canada and help it double down on its efforts to roll out 5G throughout the country.
column8: Shaw shares jumped 42% to C$34, but traded well below the offer price of C$40.50, suggesting doubts about the deal, which is valued at C$26 billion including debt. Shares of Rogers were also up 7% at C$64. (refini.tv/2OXPb4w)
column9: “It’s really too early to speculate on the regulatory outcome overall,” Rogers Chief Executive Officer Joseph Natale said on a conference call. “But we feel confident this transaction will be approved.”
column10: The deal, if completed, would be the biggest in the Canadian telecoms industry since BCE completed the spinoff of its stake in Nortel Networks in a transaction valued at C$88.7 billion in 2000, according to Refinitiv data.
column11: However, investors and analysts who expected the deal, believe regulatory risks are imminent.
column12: “Shaw was always seen as a solid fourth player in Canada. When you’re talking about taking out that fourth player, I do see that there are some regulatory risks for this,” said Stephen Duench, portfolio manager at AGF Investments, whose firm owns shares in both companies.
column13: The deal will be reviewed by the independent Competition Bureau of Canada, the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission, as well as the department of Innovation, Science and Economic Development.
column14: Canadian Innovation Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne said the review would focus on “affordability, competition, and innovation.”
column15: Canada’s telecoms industry came under the spotlight during the last federal election, with voters complaining about cellphone bills, which are among the highest in the world.
column16: In March last year, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s minority Liberal government ordered Canada’s top three top telecom operators, which together control 89.2% of the market, to cut prices on their mid-range wireless service plans by 25% within two years or face regulatory action.
column17: Sticking with its pledge of offering affordable wireless plans, Rogers said it would not raise wireless prices for Freedom Mobile customers for at least three years after the closure of the deal.
column18: Toronto-based Rogers also said it planned to spend C$2.5 billion on ramping up 5G networks in Western Canada over the next five years following its acquisition of Calgary-based Shaw.
column19: Rogers’ finance chief, Tony Staffieri, said the company was not looking to sell cable firm, Cogeco, in which it owns a 34% stake, or any other assets.
column20: The deal brings two of the country’s biggest family-founded telecom businesses together, with a combined C$19 billion in annual revenue. BCE raked in C$22.9 billion last year, while Telus had C$15 billion in revenue.

column4: UPDATE 1-Rogers Communications misses revenue estimates as media business hit
column5: (Adds background, media revenue, profit)
column6: Jan 28 (Reuters) - Canada’s Rogers Communications Inc on Thursday reported fourth-quarter revenue that fell short of Wall Street estimates, as the company’s media business took a hit due to advertising shortfalls and the postponement of live sporting events.
column7: Revenue from the media segment, which includes television, radio broadcasting and digital media fell 23% to C$409 million ($318.31 million), as the NHL and NBA seasons due to begin during the quarter were postponed, Rogers said.
column8: The telecom operator’s total revenue fell to C$3.68 billion, in the quarter ended Dec. 31, from C$3.95 billion a year ago. Analysts expected revenue of C$3.79 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column9: This comes as Rogers’ wireless services revenue, which benefits from international roaming charges, fell as fewer people traveled overseas.
column10: The Toronto-based company also faces additional pressure to grow its subscriber base in the midst of stiff competition from other telecom players looking to bring in more customers on their new 5G networks.
column11: During the quarter the company added 114,000 subscribers who pay a monthly bill, versus 138,000 in the third quarter, due to a dip in store visits from renewed pandemic restrictions.
column12: Excluding items, the company earned 99 Canadian cents per share, compared with analysts’ estimates of 98 Canadian cents per share.

column4: Canada's Rogers Communications misses quarterly revenue estimates
column5: Jan 28 (Reuters) - Canada’s Rogers Communications Inc on Thursday reported fourth-quarter revenue that fell short of Wall Street estimates, as lesser subscribers signed up for its wireless postpaid services owing to fewer store visits and increased competition.
column6: The telecom operator’s total revenue fell to C$3.68 billion ($2.86 billion) in the quarter ended Dec. 31, from C$3.95 billion a year ago. Analysts expected revenue of C$3.79 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. ($1 = 1.2862 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Eva Mathews in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: Blue Jays president, CEO Mark Shapiro nets five-year deal
column5: The Toronto Blue Jays signed team president and chief executive officer Mark Shapiro to a five-year contract extension on Wednesday.
column6: Team owner Rogers Communications announced the signing over social media for Shapiro, whose initial five-year contract with the club expired after the 2020 season.
column7: "Mark's leadership and excellence over the past five years has been critical to the team's growth and development," Edward Rogers said in a statement on Twitter. "We're extremely pleased that Mark will continue to lead the Toronto Blue Jays and build on the team's progress as we work towards our goal of bringing a World Series back to Canada."
column8: Shapiro, 53, spent 15 years in the Cleveland Indians' front office before joining the Blue Jays at the conclusion of the 2015 season.
column9: Toronto followed up its American League Championship Series appearance in 2015 with another in 2016, losing to the Indians in five games.
column10: The Blue Jays returned to the playoffs in 2020 following a 32-28 record, however they dropped both games to the Tampa Bay Rays in the wild-card round.
column11: "From a personal and professional standpoint, I am thrilled to continue being a Toronto Blue Jay," Shapiro said in a statement via the Blue Jays. "I am fortunate to work with exceptional people and am proud of the progress we have made together, to build a culture, community, and clubhouse that our incredible fans can cheer on."
column12: (Field Level Media)

column4: UPDATE 1-Canada's Rogers beats revenue estimates as sports broadcast resumes
column5: (Adds details on phone subscribers, segment wise sales)
column6: Oct 22 (Reuters) - Canada’s Rogers Communications Inc beat estimates for third-quarter revenue on Thursday, as the telecom operator’s ad sales grew after NHL hockey and sporting events resumed.
column7: Revenue from the media segment, which includes television and radio broadcasting and digital media, rose 1% to C$489 million due to resumption of sports events.
column8: The company said it added 138,000 wireless postpaid net subscribers during the quarter, up 34%, as stores reopened after coronavirus-led lockdowns.
column9: However, the company’s revenue fell about 2% to C$3.67 billion ($2.79 billion), largely driven by a 9% decrease in wireless service revenue, as fewer people opted for its roaming services.
column10: Analysts on average had expected revenue of C$3.34 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column11: Excluding items, the company earned C$1.08 per share, above analysts’ estimates of 78 Canadian cents per share.
column12: Rogers did not provide an updated financial outlook for 2020 due to uncertainties caused by the pandemic.

column4: Canada's Rogers Communications beats quarterly revenue estimates
column5: Oct 22 (Reuters) - Canada’s Rogers Communications Inc beat estimates for third-quarter revenue on Thursday, as it added more subscribers for its wireless postpaid services.
column6: The telecom operator’s revenue fell to C$3.67 billion ($2.79 billion) from C$3.75 billion a year earlier.
column7: Analysts on average had expected revenue of C$3.34 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.

column4: Altice USA, Rogers to pursue Cogeco deal despite rejection
column5: (Reuters) - Cable operator Altice USA Inc ATUS.N and Rogers Communications Inc RCIb.TO said on Thursday they will pursue deal talks for Cogeco Inc's CGO.TO assets after a C$10.3 billion bid was rejected by the Canadian telecom company's board.
column6: The offer was also rejected by Cogeco’s top investor on Wednesday.
column7: Altice USA is looking to buy the U.S. assets of Cogeco and sell the rest to Rogers Communications.

column4: Canada's Rogers expands 5G network to 50 cities and towns
column5: (Reuters) - Canadian telecom operator Rogers Communications Inc said on Tuesday it has expanded its fifth-generation (5G) telecom network to over 50 cities and towns in the country.
column6: The company, which in January became Canada’s first cellphone service provider to offer 5G, said it expects to reach 60 markets by the end of the year.
column7: The 5G network, which offers data speed that is up to 50 or 100 times faster than 4G, is expected to power everything from telemedicine, remote surgery to self-driving cars.

column4: Rogers profit misses on weakness in wireless unit and sports-starved ad sales
column5: (Reuters) - Canada's Rogers Communications Inc RCIb.TO missed quarterly revenue and profit estimates on Wednesday, as coronavirus-led restrictions hurt demand for its wireless services while cancellation of sporting activities sparked a slump in ad sales.
column6: Revenue at Rogers’ media division plunged 50% to C$296 million in the quarter as the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted major sports activities in Canada and worldwide. The company said it expects the loss in media to continue till the fourth quarter.
column7: Sports revenue for the company which owns the Toronto Blue Jays baseball team were also impacted as live events were postponed in the quarter. Rogers also owns a 37.5% stake in Maple Leaf Sports & Entertainment Ltd, which owns teams such as the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Toronto Raptors among others.
column8: Government-imposed store closures to stop the virus spread led to a decline in new subscriber additions and sale of equipment for telecom providers, some of which are also reeling from a cut in ad spend as live sports events are postponed.
column9: Revenue from roaming fell 90% in the quarter ended June 30 partly due to global travel restrictions, pulling revenue from wireless services down 13%. Revenue from its wireless equipment unit fell 17% on fewer device purchases and upgrades by existing customers.
column10: The company said it was seeing some signs of recovery in the market as lockdown measures ease and stores are allowed to re-open.
column11: “June saw a notable recovery in loading as most stores were starting to open and July is trending a little bit better as well”, Chief Financial Officer Anthony Staffieri said in an earnings call with analysts.
column12: Rogers earned C$0.60 per share, below analysts’ estimate of C$0.71 per share.
column13: Revenue fell 16.5% to C$3.16 billion, missing estimates of C$3.18 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.

column4: Rogers misses quarterly revenue estimates on lower store traffic
column5: July 22 (Reuters) - Canada’s Rogers Communications Inc on Wednesday missed revenue estimates for the second quarter, hurt by a drop in store traffic during coronavirus-led lockdowns.
column6: The telecom operator’s revenue for the quarter ended June 30 fell 16.5% to C$3.16 billion ($2.35 billion), missing estimates of C$3.18 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. ($1 = 1.3432 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Neha Malara; Editing by Shinjini Ganguli)

column4: Rogers pulls 2020 outlook, misses estimates as coronavirus crisis deepens
column5: (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc pulled its 2020 forecast and reported a lower-than-expected profit on Wednesday, as widespread cancellation of sports events hammered ad sales and demand for new routers took a hit due to the lockdowns.
column6: While telecom providers are benefiting from an increase in internet usage by customers stuck at home due to the COVID-19 pandemic, store closures have limited their ability to sell equipment and sign up new customers.
column7: Revenue from Rogers’ wireless segment, its largest business that includes internet service and equipment, slipped 2% to C$2.08 billion in the first quarter as demand dropped due to the virus outbreak and on fewer roaming calls.
column8: The equipment unit reported a 17% fall in sales on fewer device purchases and upgrades by existing customers, the company said.
column9: Canada’s Rogers Communications, which faces stiff competition from rivals BCE Corp and Telus Corp, generated average revenue per user of C$52.85 from its wireless services, compared with C$54.13 a year earlier.
column10: Revenue from Rogers’ media segment, which includes television and radio broadcasting, specialty channels and digital media, fell 12% due to the suspension of major sports matches in March and lower ad sales.
column11: The telecom operator’s revenue for the quarter ended March 31 fell 5% to C$3.42 billion, missing analysts’ estimates of C$3.53 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column12: Net income fell to C$352 million, or 68 Canadian cents per share, from C$391 million, or 76 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column13: On an adjusted basis, Rogers earned C$0.71 per share, missing estimates of C$0.80.
column14: The company’s U.S.-listed shares were marginally down in afternoon trading.

column4: Canada's Rogers withdraws 2020 outlook as coronavirus crisis deepens
column5: April 22 (Reuters) - Canada’s Rogers Communications Inc on Wednesday pulled its 2020 forecast due to uncertain economic conditions as a result of the coronavirus outbreak.
column6: The telecom operator's revenue for first quarter ended March 31 fell 5% to C$3.42 billion due to lower subscriber activity during the pandemic. (reut.rs/3529Dp1) (Reporting by Ayanti Bera in Bengaluru; Editing by Shinjini Ganguli)

column7: * ROGERS COMMUNICATIONS- TEMPORARILY CLOSED RETAIL LOCATIONS NATIONALLY Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column9: * ROGERS - CO, FIDO WILL WAIVE ROAM LIKE HOME, FIDO ROAM & PAY-PER-USE ROAMING FEES IN AVAILABLE DESTINATIONS FOR SMALL BUSINESSES UNTIL APRIL 30
column10: * ROGERS COMMUNICATIONS INC - ROGERS AND FIDO HAVE TEMPORARILY REMOVED DATA USAGE CAPS FOR CUSTOMERS ON LIMITED HOME INTERNET PLANS

column4: Canada's Rogers expects to spend up to C$2.9 billion in 2020
column5: (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc RCIb.TO said on Wednesday it expects to spend up to C$2.9 billion ($2.21 billion) this year to expand its communications infrastructure in Canada, including for 5G, but warned that "punitive" regulations would slow the deployment of the high speed network.
column6: Lack of “right” regulations in Canada to build 5G infrastructure puts the proposed investment at risk, Chief Executive Officer Joe Natale said.
column7: “As we enter the world of 5G, regulatory certainty is critical to investment,” Natale said on a post-earnings call.
column8: Canada is reviewing the security implications of 5G networks, including whether to allow China’s Huawei Technologies to supply network equipment.
column9: The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC) could not be immediately reached for comment.
column10: Countries including the United States, China, South Korea and Japan are in a race to speed up 5G adoption, hoping the technology will spur breakthrough in the development of smart cities and autonomous cars, among other things.
column11: “The race to 5G is not with other companies, it is with other countries,” Natale said on a post-earnings call.
column12: Rogers became Canada’s first cellphone services provider to offer 5G telecom services, as it started rolling out the technology in downtown Vancouver, Toronto, Ottawa and Montreal last week.
column13: The company has partnered with Sweden's Ericsson ERICb.ST for the technology needed to build its 5G network and has plans to expand to another 20 markets by the end of the year.
column14: Shares of the company were up nearly 4% in morning trade, as it posted higher year-over-year revenue and added 131,000 net wireless postpaid subscribers in the quarter ended Dec. 31.
column15: (This story corrects capital expenditure figure to “up to C$2.9 billion” from “$3 billion” and clarifies Rogers would spend to “expand communication infrastructure”, not just for “5G infrastructure” in headline, paragraph 1.)

column4: Rogers Communications misses Wall Street quarterly estimates
column5: (Reuters) - Canada's Rogers Communications Inc RCIb.TO missed Wall Street estimates for its fourth-quarter core earnings as more people continued to shift to its unlimited data plan, leading to a decrease in its revenues from charging customers for additional data usage.
column6: The company faces stiff competition from rivals BCE Corp BCE.TO and Telus Corp T.TO, especially on the pricing of its wireless plans and country wide 5G network roll-out.
column7: Rogers, which started its 5G infrastructure roll-out last week, generated average revenue per user of C$55.26 from its wireless services, compared with C$55.91, a year earlier.
column8: The company’s net income fell to C$468 million or 92 Canadian cents per share in the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2019 from C$502 million, or 97 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column9: On an adjusted basis, it earned C$1 per share, missing analysts’ average estimate of C$1.02, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column10: The Toronto-based company’s total revenue rose marginally to C$3.95 billion, just shy of analysts’ estimates of C$3.96 billion.
column11: The telecom operator expects full-year revenue for 2020 to be in a range of 2% rise to 2% fall.

column4: CORRECTED-Rogers Communications fourth-quarter revenue rises
column5: (Corrects headline and text to say fourth-quarter revenue rose, not fell)
column6: Jan 22 (Reuters) - Canada’s Rogers Communications Inc said on Wednesday its quarterly revenue rose marginally to C$3.95 billion ($3.02 billion) in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31.
column7: Net income fell to C$468 million, or 92 Canadian cents per share, from C$502 million, or 97 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier. ($1 = 1.3061 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Ambhini Aishwarya in Bengaluru; Editing by Vinay Dwivedi)

column4: Rogers begins roll out of 5G network in major Canadian cities
column5: TORONTO (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc said on Wednesday it has started rolling out the fifth-generation (5G) telecoms network in some Canadian cities, becoming the country’s first cellphone provider to offer the super-fast telecom services.
column6: Rogers, one of Canada’s largest wireless carriers, will launch first in downtown Vancouver, Toronto, Ottawa, and Montreal, before expanding into over 20 more markets by the end of the year, in advance of 5G-enabled devices becoming available this year, the statement added.
column7: “5G is the biggest technological evolution since the launch of wireless in Canada. We are making the right investments, building the right partnerships and deploying the right technology to bring Canadians the very best of 5G,” said Joe Natale, chief executive of Rogers Communications.
column8: The 5G networks will have speeds fast enough to download a movie to a smartphone in seconds, while allowing businesses to run ‘smart’ factories using connected robots, devices and sensors.
column9: Rogers has partnered with Sweden’s Ericsson to provide the technology needed to build the network.
column10: Canada is reviewing the security implications of 5G networks, including whether to allow China’s Huawei Technologies to supply 5G network equipment.
column11: The roll-out puts Rogers, which was founded in 1960 by a Canadian entrepreneur, ahead of its competition - Bell Canada, a unit of BCE Corp, and Telus Corp, Canada’s two other major telecoms companies.
column12: Bell is ready to launch similarly early-stage 5G networks when devices become available, the company said in an emailed statement.
column13: “Canada has the opportunity to lead the world in 5G if our regulatory environment continues to encourage wireless infrastructure investment,” the statement added. “Policies that hamper or restrict the significant capital investment required will lead to the opposite outcome.”
column14: Telus did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
column15: Canada’s top five telecom companies accounted for 85% of the broadcast and telecommunications industry’s C$67.6 billion ($50.8 billion) revenues in 2017 in Canada, the most recent government figures show.
column16: Rogers also said it was joining a global alliance with other major telecoms companies from around the world, to coordinate on delivery of 5G adoption.
column17: The other companies in the 5G Future Forum are U.S. firm Verizon, Mexico’s América Móvil, South Korea-based KT Corp, Australia’s Telstra and Vodafone in Europe.
column18: The forum is intended to ensure that 5G networks from service providers in different countries will be able to communicate seamlessly with each other.

column4: Rogers begins roll out of 5G network in major Canadian cities
column5: TORONTO, Jan 15 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc said on Wednesday it has started rolling out the fifth-generation (5G) telecoms network in Canada’s select cities, becoming the country’s first cellphone provider to offer the super-fast telecom services.
column6: Rogers, one of Canada’s largest wireless carriers, will launch first in downtown Vancouver, Toronto, Ottawa and Montreal before expanding into over 20 more markets by the end of the year, in advance of 5G-enabled devices becoming available this year, the statement added.
column7: “5G is the biggest technological evolution since the launch of wireless in Canada. We are making the right investments, building the right partnerships and deploying the right technology to bring Canadians the very best of 5G,” said Joe Natale, CEO of Rogers Communications.
column8: “5G will not only power businesses, it will fuel entire industries and drive Canada’s digital future,” he added.
column9: The 5G networks will have speeds fast enough to download a movie to a smartphone in seconds, while allowing businesses to run ‘smart’ factories using connected robots, devices and sensors.
column10: Rogers has partnered with Sweden’s Ericsson to provide the technology needed to build the network.
column11: Canada is reviewing security implications of 5G networks, including whether to allow China’s Huawei Technologies to supply 5G network equipment.
column12: Rogers also said it is joining a global alliance with other major telecoms companies from around the world, to coordinate on delivery of 5G adoption.
column13: The other companies in the 5G Future Forum are Verizon , América Móvil, South Korea-based KT Corp, Australia’s Telstra and Vodafone in Europe.
column14: The forum will focus on ensuring that 5G networks from different service providers in various countries will be able to communicate seamlessly with each other. (Reporting by Moira Warburton in Toronto; Editing by David Gregorio)

column4: Rogers Communications cuts full-year revenue, core profit forecasts
column5: (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc RCIb.TO cut its full-year sales and core earnings forecasts on Wednesday, as the Canadian company's revenue from sale of additional data packages took a hit from customers switching to its new unlimited data plans.
column6: The company’s shares fell 6% to hit their lowest in more than a year at C$6.43.
column7: Rogers said revenue from charging customers for data used above their monthly limit fell by about C$50 million ($38.19 million) in the third quarter.
column8: It expects the revenue decline from customers shifting to the unlimited plans to be spread over four to five quarters, compared with its earlier expectation of six to eight quarters.
column9: The company’s unlimited data plan, Rogers Infinite, launched late in the second quarter, has about 1 million subscribers.
column10: Rogers now expects 2019 revenue to be broadly flat compared with an earlier forecast of 3%-5% growth.
column11: Adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization are now expected to grow 3%-5%, lower than its prior expectation of 7%-9%.
column12: The company, which has been spending heavily on developing 5G infrastructure across the country, said it added 103,000 wireless subscribers in the quarter, lower than the 124,000 it added a year earlier.
column13: Rogers generated average billings per user of C$67.20 for its wireless services compared with C$66.20 a year earlier.
column14: Excluding items, it earned C$1.19 per share, missing the average analyst estimate of C$1.31 per share, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column15: Net income fell to C$593 million, or C$1.14 per share, from C$594 million, or C$1.15 per share, a year earlier.
column16: Revenue fell just about 1% to C$3.75 billion ($2.86 billion).

column4: CANADA STOCKS-TSX slips on disappointing Rogers outlook, weak energy sector
column5: Oct 23 (Reuters) - Canada’s main stock index fell on Wednesday, pressured by a dour revenue forecast from Rogers Communications and a drop in energy shares, with losses limited by gains in material stocks.
column6: * At 9:56 a.m. ET (13:56 GMT), the Toronto Stock Exchange’s S&P/TSX composite index was down 19.9 points, or 0.18%, at 16,371.62.
column7: * Rogers Communications Inc fell 6% after lowering its full-year revenue forecast, triggering a 2% decline in the communication services index.
column8: * The energy sector slipped 0.7%, as U.S. crude prices declined 0.9% a barrel, while Brent crude lost 0.7%.
column9: * The financials sector dipped 0.1%, while the consumer index fell about half a percent.
column10: * The materials sector, which includes precious and base metals miners, was among the few bright spots, up 1% as gold futures rose 0.3% to $1,486.4 an ounce. ]
column11: * On the TSX, 111 issues were higher, while 109 issues declined for a 1.02-to-1 ratio favouring gainers, with 12.51 million shares traded.
column12: * The largest percentage gainers on the TSX were Eldorado Gold, which jumped 4.2%, and Agnico Eagle Miners , which rose 2.5%.
column13: * The most heavily traded shares by volume were Aurora Cannabis, Rogers Communications and Zenabis Gllobal Inc.
column14: * The TSX posted two new 52-week highs and four new lows.
column15: * Across all Canadian issues there were five new 52-week highs and 13 new lows, with total volume of 22.23 million shares. (Reporting by Agamoni Ghosh; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila)

column4: CORRECTED-UPDATE 1-Rogers Communications lowers full-year revenue forecast due to fewer subscriber additions
column5: (Corrects paragraph 2 to say postpaid wireless subscriber additions numbers fell to “103,000”, not “103 million” from “124,000”, not “124 million”)
column6: Oct 23 (Reuters) - Canada’s Rogers Communications Inc cut its full-year revenue forecast on Wednesday after the company added fewer wireless subscribers in the third quarter due to stiff competition.
column7: The net postpaid wireless subscriber additions in the quarter fell to 103,000 from 124,000 a year earlier, in spite of the company’s heavy spending on developing 5G infrastructure across the country to attract more customers.
column8: The company now expects full-year revenue growth to roughly stay flat, compared with an earlier forecast of a 3% to 5% growth.
column9: The Toronto-based company generated an average revenue per user of C$67.20 for its wireless services, compared to C$66.20, the previous year, beating analysts’ estimates of C$57.71 per user.
column10: Excluding items, it earned C$1.19 per share missing average analysts’ estimate of C$1.31 cents per share, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. The Canadian phone company’s net income fell to C$593 million ($452.88 million)or C$1.14 per share, from C$594 million, or C$1.15 per share, a year earlier.
column11: Revenue fell just about 1% to C$3.75 billion ($2.86 billion). ($1 = 1.3094 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Ambhini Aishwarya in Bengaluru; Editing by Vinay Dwivedi)

column4: Rogers Communications reports a fall in third-quarter profit
column5: Oct 23 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc reported a fall in its third-quarter profit on Wednesday on lower subscription growth.
column6: The Canadian phone company’s net income fell to C$593 million ($452.81 million)or C$1.14 per share, from C$594 million, or C$1.15 per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue fell just about 1% to C$3.75 billion ($2.86 billion). ($1 = 1.3096 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Ambhini Aishwarya in Bengaluru; Editing by Vinay Dwivedi)

column4: Rogers quarterly profit misses on fewer wireless subscriber additions
column5: (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc, Canada’s largest wireless carrier, on Tuesday reported a slightly lower-than-expected quarterly profit in a softer market that hit subscriber additions.
column6: The telecom company, which has been enduring tougher competition, added just 77,000 net postpaid wireless subscribers in the second quarter ended June 30, down from 122,000 new customers a year earlier.
column7: Rogers, among Canada’s Big Three telecoms, was the first in the country to introduce unlimited data plans last month, which was quickly followed by rivals BCE Inc’s Bell Mobility and Telus Corp.
column8: The company said 365,000 customers have already switched to the newly introduced “Infinite” data plan and their usage grew 50% within six weeks of its launch.
column9: Rogers expects a short-term moderation in growth with respect to the new data plan, Chief Financial Officer Anthony Staffieri said on a conference call.
column10: Analysts expect Canadian telecom companies to face near-term pressure as customers migrate to unlimited plans, which will affect average revenue per user (ARPU).
column11: However, the company’s wireless customers on an average paid C$56.73 ($43.15) a month for its services in the quarter, up from C$55.60 a year earlier.
column12: Desjardins analyst Maher Yaghi said the acceleration of wireless ARPU is encouraging as it could lift expectations.
column13: The company is entering a period of higher ARPU base after the launch, which is a positive sign, Yaghi wrote in a note.
column14: The Toronto-based company’s net income rose 10% to C$591 million, or C$1.15 per share, in the quarter.
column15: On an adjusted basis, the company earned C$1.16 per share, missing analysts’ estimates by 1 Canadian cent, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column16: Revenue rose 0.6% to C$3.78 billion, falling below analysts’ estimates of C$3.87 billion.
column17: The company’s shares, which fell as much as 3%, were down 1.1% at C$69.16.

column4: Rogers Communications second-quarter profit rises 10%
column5: July 23 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc on Tuesday reported a nearly 10% rise in quarterly profit, as the Canadian telecom company benefited from growth in its wireless and cable segments.
column6: The Toronto-based company’s net income rose to C$591 million ($449.9 million), or C$1.15 per share, in the second quarter ended June 30, from C$538 million, or C$1.04 per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue rose to C$3.78 billion from C$3.76 billion. ($1 = 1.3135 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Arundhati Sarkar in Bengaluru; Editing by James Emmanuel)

column4: Rogers Communications quarterly profit misses estimates
column5: (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc on Thursday reported a quarterly profit that missed estimates on lower revenue from its media business.
column6: Total media revenue fell 12 percent to C$468 million. The year-ago quarter had recorded a distribution from Major League Baseball to the Toronto Blue Jays.
column7: Excluding the impact, media revenue would have been stable year-on-year, the company said.
column8: Wireless revenue declined marginally during the quarter.
column9: Excluding one-time items, Rogers earned 78 Canadian cents per share during the first quarter, while analysts on an average had estimated a profit of 94 Canadian cents, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column10: The Toronto-based company’s net income fell to C$391 million ($292.45 million), or 76 Canadian cents per share, in the first quarter ended March 31, from C$425 million, or 80 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column11: Total quarterly revenue fell to C$3.59 billion from C$3.63 billion.

column4: Rogers Communications quarterly profit falls 8 pct
column5: April 18 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc reported an 8 percent fall in quarterly profit on Thursday, as the company recorded lower revenue in both its wireless equipment and media segments.
column6: The Toronto-based company’s net income fell to C$391 million ($292.45 million), or 76 Canadian cents per share, in the first quarter ended March 31, from C$425 million, or 80 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Total revenue fell to C$3.59 billion from C$3.63 billion.

column4: Rogers Communications quarterly profit beats on subscriber additions
column5: (Reuters) - Canada's Rogers Communications Inc RCIb.TO on Thursday beat analysts' estimates for quarterly profit, as the cable and telecom company's investments in its wireless business paid off and it signed up more subscribers.
column6: One of Canada’s Big Three telecoms, Rogers has been spending heavily on customer service and wireless networks to win in the country’s fast-growing mobile market where aggressive discounts and promotions are common baits for attracting customers.
column7: The company said it added 112,000 net postpaid subscribers in the fourth-quarter ended Dec. 31, 2018, up from 72,000 new customers a year earlier.
column8: On average, Rogers’ wireless customers paid C$55.91 a month for its services, up from C$54.95 a year ago.
column9: The Toronto-based company said its postpaid churn rate, the pace at which customers exit subscription, fell 0.25 points to 1.23 percent during the quarter.
column10: Last week, smaller rival Shaw Communications reported a profit beat, also driven by monthly postpaid customers additions.
column11: Rogers has also been getting 5G-ready with various acquisitions across the country. It has partnered with mobile telecom equipment maker Ericsson for 5G trials in Toronto and Ottawa among other cities.
column12: Fifth-generation technology is expected to greatly enhance speed and coverage with almost no time lag. Canadian providers, which are behind their U.S. counterparts, are now focusing on getting their fair share of the technology.
column13: Rogers said it has signed a three-year partnership with the University of British Columbia to create what the company says will be Canada’s first “real-world” 5G hub.
column14: The company said despite spending heavily, it expects revenue and adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization to grow in 2019.
column15: It expects to spend between C$2.85 billion and C$3.05 billion in 2019, the upper range of which is ahead of the C$2.86 billion analysts at Barclays were expecting.
column16: Rogers’ net income rose to C$502 million ($375.78 million), in the reported quarter, from C$499 million.
column17: On a per share basis, the company earned 97 Canadian cents per share, flat compared with a year earlier.
column18: On an adjusted basis, it earned C$1.13. Analysts on average had expected earnings of C$1.08, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column19: Revenue rose 6 percent to C$3.94 billion.
column20: Shares of the company closed at C$72.61 on Wednesday.

column4: Rogers Communications quarterly profit rises on subscriber addition
column5: Jan 24 (Reuters) - Canadian cable and telecom operator Rogers Communications Inc on Thursday reported a rise in quarterly profit, as more subscribers joined its postpaid wireless services.
column6: The Toronto-based company’s net income rose to C$502 million ($375.78 million), in the fourth quarter ended Dec.31, from C$499 million.
column7: On a per share basis, the company earned 97 Canadian cents per share, flat compared with a year earlier.
column8: Revenue rose to C$3.94 billion from C$3.73 billion.

column4: UPDATE 1-Rogers Communications profit beats on wireless, cable strength
column5: (Adds details on cable and wireless businesses, compares with estimates)
column6: Oct 19 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit on Friday as the Canadian telecom company benefited from strong growth in its wireless and cable businesses.
column7: Revenue from the wireless business rose 5.8 pct to C$2.33 billion ($1.79 billion), while revenue from its cable business edged up nearly 1 percent to C$983 million.
column8: The company has been investing heavily to develop its 5G wireless network through acquisitions across the country. It has partnered with telecom equipment maker Ericsson for 5G network trials.
column9: Canada’s largest wireless provider said it added 124,000 postpaid wireless subscribers on a net basis in third quarter.
column10: The Toronto-based company's net income rose 17 percent to C$594 million, or C$1.15 per share, in the third quarter ended Sept. 30. [bit.ly/2yxB9vN ]
column11: Excluding one-time items, Rogers earned C$1.21 per share, ahead of analysts’ average estimate of C$1.17, according to data from Refinitiv.
column12: Revenue rose to C$3.77 billion from C$3.65 billion. ($1 = 1.3036 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Shanti S Nair in Bengaluru; Editing by James Emmanuel)

column4: Rogers Communications quarterly profit rises 17 pct
column5: Oct 19 (Reuters) - Canadian telecom company Rogers Communications Inc reported a 17 percent rise in quarterly profit on Friday, helped by growth in its wireless and cable businesses.
column6: The Toronto-based company’s net income rose to C$594 million ($455.38 million), or C$1.15 per share, in the third quarter ended Sept. 30, from C$508 million, or 98 Canadian cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue rose to C$3.77 billion from C$3.65 billion. ($1 = 1.3044 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Shanti S Nair in Bengaluru)

column4: Canada's Rogers holds fire on guidance after subscriber jump
column5: (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc RCIb.TO topped analysts' estimates for quarterly profit on Thursday as it drew greater numbers of subscribers into high-priced postpaid mobile phone contracts, but it stopped short of upgrading annual profit guidance.
column6: Canada’s largest wireless provider has been investing heavily in customer service and its various networks, leading to a net addition of 122,000 postpaid wireless subscribers, who pay for services monthly, during the quarter.
column7: That was up from the 93,000 users it added at the same time last year and 95,000 in the previous quarter.
column8: Several sector analysts, however, were taken aback that the company had not seen enough to raise its forecasts for this year and shares in the company fell 2.5 percent after opening in Toronto.
column9: “We were surprised that management did not raise guidance despite the strong year-to-date,” Phillip Huang of Barclays Capital Inc wrote in a note.
column10: Other analysts asked managers during an earnings call why the company was being conservative on its outlook given the results.
column11: The Toronto-based company said on average wireless customers paid 4 percent more per month in the quarter ended June 30.
column12: The postpaid churn rate - the pace at which subscribers leave - fell to its lowest in nine years at 1.01 percent.
column13: Efforts to improve services for customers has “reflected in reduced churn, reduced calls into our call center, along with the solid uptick in digital adoption,” chief executive Joseph Natale said on a call with analysts.
column14: An attempt by Peer Shaw Communications SJRb.TO to break into Canada's mobile market by undercutting existing players on price has put pressure on Rogers, Telus Corp T.TO and BCE Inc BCE.TO.
column15: Rogers said it invested C$240-million in its wireless business in the second quarter, up 52 per cent from the same time last year. For cable, it upped investment 24 percent to C$352 million.
column16: The company, which has been testing streaming device Ignite TV in Ontario in the face of competition from BCE’s upgraded fiber network, said the “soft-launch” had drawn positive reviews from customers in the second quarter.
column17: Natale said that Ignite TV was “just the beginning” of a connected home solution, that could remotely control everything from home security to lighting and temperature control.
column18: Rogers’ net income rose to C$538 million ($406.34 million), or C$1.04 per share, in the quarter, from C$528 million, or C$1.02 per share, a year earlier.
column19: Revenue rose to C$3.76 billion from C$3.62 billion.
column20: Excluding one-time items, the company earned C$1.07 per share, while analysts had on average expected C$1.05, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.

column4: Rogers Communications reports higher quarterly profit
column5: July 19 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc reported a 2 percent rise in quarterly profit on Thursday as more subscribers signed up for the Canadian telecom company’s wireless postpaid services.
column6: The Toronto-based company’s net income rose to C$538 million ($406.34 million), or C$1.04 per share, in the second quarter ended June 30, from C$528 million, or C$1.02 per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue rose to C$3.76 billion from C$3.62 billion. ($1 = 1.3240 Canadian dollars) (Reporting by Karan Nagarkatti in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)

column4: CANADA STOCKS-TSX rises, led by financials and Rogers Communications
CANADA STOCKS-TSX rises, led by financials, Rogers Communications
column5: TORONTO, April 20 (Reuters) - Canada’s main stock index rose on Friday as higher bond yields boosted financials, while shares of Rogers Communications jumped after the telecommunications company reported profits that beat estimates.
column6: The Toronto Stock Exchange’s S&P/TSX composite index unofficially closed up 29.9 points, or 0.19 percent, at 15,484.32. Six of the index’s 10 main groups ended higher. (Reporting by Fergal Smith; Editing by Dan Grebler)

column4: Rogers tops profit estimates as wireless subscriber base grows
column5: (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc's RCIb.TO first-quarter profit topped analysts' forecasts as the Canadian cable and telecom company signed up more wireless postpaid and internet customers.
column6: Rogers, Canada’s largest wireless company by market share, said on Thursday it added 95,000 net postpaid wireless subscribers in the first three months of 2018, up by 35,000 compared with a year earlier.
column7: Toronto-based Rogers has been focusing on growing its wireless network as it faces fierce competition from Telus Corp T.TO, BCE Inc BCE.TO and Shaw Communications Inc SJRb.TO.
column8: Rogers’ net income rose to C$425 million ($335.7 million) or 80 Canadian cents per share in the first quarter, from C$310 million or 60 Canadian cents per share a year earlier.
column9: Excluding one-time items, Rogers earned 90 Canadian cents per share, ahead of analysts’ average estimate of 75 Canadian cents, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column10: Revenue rose 7.7 percent to C$3.63 billion.

column4: Rogers Communications' quarterly profit rises 37 pct
column5: April 19 (Reuters) - Rogers Communications Inc’s first-quarter profit rose 37 percent as the Canadian cable and telecom company signed up more wireless postpaid and internet customers.
column6: Toronto-based Rogers said on Thursday its net income rose to C$425 million ($335.7 million) or 80 Canadian cents per share in the three months ended March 31, from C$310 million or 60 Canadian cents per share a year earlier.
